text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text occupies the lower half of the folio; a large square miniature of the Crucifixion fills the upper half. Wide margins on the right, left, and bottom are densely filled with delicate foliate scrollwork, small animals, and grotesques. A single historiated initial ‘D’ in gold, blue, and red marks the opening line beneath the miniature.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with consistent stroke width, numerous standard abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf used for halos and decorative bezants in borders; ultramarine applied to the sky and decorative initials; vermilion for the executioners' garments and rubricated text; green for the grassy hill and foliate borders; white highlights model folds and details. Alternating blue and red initials create a rhythmic pattern. Colors are layered with fine white underpaint, well preserved with minimal darkening of lead white.

features: Central figure of Christ seated on a rocky outcrop with halo
Diagonal axes defined by the wooden cross beams and mallet
Virgin Mary and St John flanking left side, forming a triangular grouping
Two executioners at lower right and left engaging the cross elements
Gestural emphasis directs gaze upward toward Christ’s face

decorative_elements: Openwork foliate borders with acanthus leaves and vine scrolls
Grotesque marginal creatures including a stork-like bird and insect
Historiated initial ‘D’ with white vine pattern on blue and red ground
Gold bezants marking junctions in border stems

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown-black ink with varying thickness; clear underdrawing visible at edges
drawing_technique.shading_method: Layered washes of pigment with subtle tonal gradations; white lead highlights on drapery folds and flesh
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; spatial depth suggested by overlapping figures and receding ground line

content_theme.scene_description: A single, full-square miniature depicts the despondent Christ, semi-nude and marked by scourge wounds, seated on a grassy mound at center. He bears a gilded halo inscribed with the cross. To his left, two figures enact the raising of the cross: one man in vermilion tunic kneels on one knee, grasping a timber beam, while another stands behind him holding a large wooden mallet mid-swing. Behind them, the Virgin Mary dressed in blue kneels, her hand covering her mouth in sorrow. To Christ’s right, St John the Evangelist in red with a green headdress bends forward, holding a cluster of iron nails. A bloodstained red cloth lies draped across the foreground beam. The background features a luminous ultramarine sky with stylized clouds and a gently rolling green hill. Figures are arranged in a near-pyramidal composition, scale emphasizing Christ’s central importance. Overlapping limbs and beams create shallow depth. Costumes are rendered with fine brushwork: soft folds in Mary’s mantle, pleated tunics on the executioners, and the diaphanous shroud around Christ’s waist. The scene is framed by a thin gold fillet and black line border that separates it from the surrounding text and margins.

secular: Two executioners preparing the cross beams

natural: Stylized acanthus leaves and vine scrolls in margins
Stork-like bird perched in right margin

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, very smooth with faint hair follicle pattern; consistent parchment thickness; impossible to discern folio arrangement from single leaf
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent color retention; minor cockling at lower edge; slight abrasion of gold in sky border; minimal pigment flaking confined to red garment folds
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in halos and bezants
Fine ink underdrawing visible under UV light
Regular ruling pattern present beneath text
Evidence of later 19th-century retouch in blue sky

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth and piety
Meditative aid focusing on the Passion
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual lay patron for personal prayer and contemplation

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illumination of the Crucifixion likely originates from a late 15th-century Ghent–Bruges workshop, reflecting the flourishing book-trade that catered to wealthy lay patrons in the Burgundian Netherlands. The sumptuous application of burnished gold leaf and fine ultramarine indicates access to high-quality imported pigments, characteristic of private Books of Hours produced for courtly clientele. The intricate white-vine border, punctuated by naturalistic birds and grotesques, exemplifies the classical revival in marginal ornament, while the use of a single square miniature aligns with the devotional function of pausing at each Passion episode. Stylistically, the restrained perspectival treatment and hierarchical scaling adhere to established medieval conventions, yet the subtle modeling of flesh and intricate underdrawing reveal an innovative attention to naturalism. Workshop practices are evident in the collaborative hands: a master delineated the Christ figure and principal contours, while assistants executed border foliage and secondary figures. Iconographically, the composition emphasizes Christ’s redemptive suffering, counterbalanced by the maternal sorrow of Mary and the youthful compassion of John, inviting empathetic meditation. Compared to contemporary Parisian Hours, this page exhibits a more restrained palette and tighter modeling, suggesting regional variation. The work thus represents a transitional moment combining traditional Passion iconography with early Northern Renaissance refinements in pigment layering and border invention.
